metadata.synopsis: The party discuss what just occurred and what to do about their current situation.They failed to kill the Netherbrain and the Emperor has other plans in mind. Gale and Lae'zel are given a higher priority here since Gale has the bomb in his chest and Lae'zel may want to free Orpheus.The main topics:1. What Is Happening2.  Distrust3. Hope
metadata.how_to_trigger: Act 3 > Endgame > Astral Plane > Trigger END_IllithidOptions_EmperorProposal > GD

129.speaker: Player
129.text: The Emperor did this. Planned this, somehow. What's it hiding?

121.speaker: Player
121.text: I have no love for the illithid - but its survival is bound to ours. That is as close to common cause as we will get.

68.speaker: Player
68.text: Let's hear the Emperor out. We can make our minds up then.

78.speaker: Player
78.text: |Best to make such decisions after thorough research.|

39.speaker: Player
39.text: Hear, hear. Still hoping for a miracle, but I'm ready for whatever comes our way.

46.speaker: Player
46.text: Whatever the Emperor has to say, I'm past the point of trusting it.

6.speaker: Player
6.text: I'm not sure I ever really did. That thing is in it for itself, all the way.

109.speaker: Player
109.text: |Then we'll need to make our next move carefully. While my option is available, I'm not eager to using it if it can be avoided.|

7.speaker: Player
7.text: Trust me - unleashing the orb is not something I want to do, but if there's no other way...
7.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale gives a sage nod.

8.speaker: Player
8.text: ...well, I shan't hesitate. We cannot allow this thing to prevail.
8.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale gives a sage nod.

3.speaker: Player
3.text: The Emperor's plan only failed because the brain evolved - let's hear it out. It might have a solution yet.

13.speaker: Player
13.text: The flayer makes a great show of having all the answers. Let us see if it can save its own skin.

85.speaker: Player
85.text: We have another option - the orb. I could still put a stop to this... though at great cost.

97.speaker: Player
97.text: And I thought myself the pragmatist. No, Gale - better to die for the right choice than live with the wrong one.

37.speaker: Player
37.text: Not a price I really want to pay, but if we run out of options, we might have to fork up.

108.speaker: Player
108.text: I think we should free Orpheus - perhaps he can help us where the Emperor failed.

43.speaker: Player
43.text: The Emperor fears Orpheus. Do not expect it to stand idly by and see him freed.

83.speaker: Player
83.text: Who cares what squiddie thinks? Our goal was never to save the damn thing. If Orpheus can help us, we should give him a chance.

9.speaker: Player
9.text: The Emperor will no doubt seek to pour honey in our ears - talk us round to it's way of thinking. It would be remiss of me to not remind all that there is another way...

35.speaker: Player
35.text: ... the orb. I still have the means to unleash its power, and put a stop to all this from one heartbeat to the next. But it would not be without cost. The city, and all who remain, would be lost.

27.speaker: Player
27.text: It should not have to come to that. Perhaps the illithid can provide us with a better solution.

10.speaker: Narrator
10.text: *Discomfort gnaws at you like a rat in your belly - is it doubt? Or simply fear?*
10.context: NodeContext: 'guest' = the tadpole living in your head.

42.speaker: Narrator
42.text: *The stones were supposed to allow you to dominate the brain - the Emperor said so. But it didn't work.*

69.speaker: Narrator
69.text: *There is another way - the hammer that will free Orpheus. Perhaps the githyanki could help you succeed, where the mind flayer failed?*

66.speaker: Narrator
66.text: *If only you could free Orpheus, perhaps he could help you succeed where the Emperor failed?*

101.speaker: Narrator
101.text: *And then there's the fire in your chest, filling you with white, hot, power, ready to be released at any moment.*

72.speaker: Player
72.text: Don't be daft. The Emperor misled us. Planned this whole thing. What's it hiding?

16.speaker: Player
16.text: The Emperor will no doubt seek to pour honey in our ears - talk us round to it's way of thinking. It would be remiss of me to not remind all that there is another way...

31.speaker: Player
31.text: ... the orb. I still have the means to unleash its power, and put a stop to all this from one heartbeat to the next. But it would not be without cost. The city, and all who remain, would be lost.

44.speaker: Player
44.text: | So our choices are: Trust the scheming mindflayer or Disintegrate the Sword Coast... |

111.speaker: Player
111.text: Let's hear what the Emperor has to say - we can make our minds up then.

76.speaker: Player
76.text: That's it. Get the facts, then sort them out. Not like we have much of a choice to do otherwise.

102.speaker: Player
102.text: The Emperor's plan failed. It's proven it can't be trusted.

52.speaker: Player
52.text: |Then that will not leave us with many options left. Measure twice, cut once.|

60.speaker: Player
60.text: Look at Gale, look down to his chest.

56.speaker: Player
56.text: As keen as I am to survive, the option remains - and we have vanishingly few others. I daresay none.
56.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale gives a sage nod.

34.speaker: Player
34.text: We may cling to hope a while longer if you wish, but should that fail us, I'll be ready to act.
34.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale gives a sage nod.

100.speaker: Player
100.text: The Emperor's plan only failed because the brain has evolved - it might have another plan.

54.speaker: Player
54.text: I'm willing to hear this so-called plan. Also willing to split the thing's skull open, but I can wait.

91.speaker: Player
91.text: We have another option - the orb. I could still put a stop to this... though at great cost.

29.speaker: Player
29.text: No, we cannot resort to that - not if there's even a glimmer of hope remaining. If we're willing to sacrifice a whole city of innocents, what are we even fighting for?

73.speaker: Player
73.text: | I won't accept it. I won't. |

124.speaker: Player
124.text: I say we free Orpheus. Perhaps he can help us where the Emperor failed.

80.speaker: Player
80.text: |Nothing like a good one-two with a blunt object to shift negotiations, though it doesn't seem like the type to appreciate such crude methods.|

0.speaker: Player
0.text: Who cares what the illithid thinks. If we can get Orpheus on our side, we're golden.

23.speaker: Player
23.text: The Emperor will no doubt seek to pour honey in our ears - talk us round to it's way of thinking. It would be remiss of me to not remind all that there is another way...

105.speaker: Player
105.text: ... the orb. I still have the means to unleash its power, and put a stop to all this from one heartbeat to the next. But it would not be without cost. The city, and all who remain, would be lost.

41.speaker: Player
41.text: Why in the hells would we do that?!

118.speaker: Player
118.text: The end is nigh, one way or another, and our options are dwindling in both quantity and quality.

132.speaker: Player
132.text: You distrust the Emperor that much?

92.speaker: Player
92.text: Honestly? I think putting trust in anyone but ourselves is foolhardy at this stage. One way or another, I think we amount to the best chance of stopping this.

120.speaker: Player
120.text: That's not our only option - we could still free Orpheus.

113.speaker: Player
113.text: A githyanki who might turn on us for being infected? That is not someone I'm eager to pin my hopes on.

86.speaker: Player
86.text: Present company excluded of course - but the point remains. We cannot afford to trust your kin will react well to us.

45.speaker: Player
45.text: The orb is not a choice that I relish... but it is not one we can afford to ignore.

67.speaker: Player
67.text: Let's not rush to conclusions - we should at least hear what the Emperor has to say.

14.speaker: Player
14.text: Hear him out if you wish - but please, don't act in haste.

30.speaker: Player
30.text: Of course - I've had ample time to think on it. We may yet prevail by other means... but the option remains. And I shall not hesitate, if called upon.

115.speaker: Player
115.text: Either way, I think we should free Orpheus.

93.speaker: Player
93.text: If that is your wish, so be it... but the orb remains an option. And I shall not hesitate, if called upon.

90.speaker: Player
90.text: We've gone astray. Foolish to think the Emperor would lead us to anything but ruin.

126.speaker: Player
126.text: Whatever the ghaik proposes, we must have but one goal in mind: free Orpheus from his shackles.

114.speaker: Player
114.text: The Prince of the Comet will reclaim the throne from the traitorous lich queen.

70.speaker: Player
70.text: The Netherstones failed, the brain still lives. Orpheus is hardly my top concern.

53.speaker: Player
53.text: Then you will make him your concern.

128.speaker: Player
128.text: The Githyanki Empire is at a precipice - one wrong push, and it tumbles.

33.speaker: Player
33.text: Let's talk to the Emperor first before we decide anything.

36.speaker: Player
36.text: Watch your tone. I will do what's right, no more and no less.

106.speaker: Player
106.text: My fate unravels, and you're concerned with my tone? Fagh wo'h chox, kainyank!
106.context: NodeContext: fahg woh CHALKS, cane-yank! (Fuck off, cursed one!)

63.speaker: Player
63.text: Speak to the Emperor, entertain its tall tales if it suits you.

94.speaker: Player
94.text: But do not forget my sacred mission. Vlaakith demands we sever the prince's blasphemous head.

55.speaker: Player
55.text: Do this, and the queen's forces will aid us against the Netherbrain.

103.speaker: Player
103.text: Speak to the Emperor if you must. But it will cajole you with empty promises, coax you with lies. There is only one answer it deserves:

58.speaker: Player
58.text: I have your back. We will liberate Orpheus.

74.speaker: Player
74.text: The Emperor will resist. It will lie, it will cajole - it might even beg. But there is only one answer it deserves:

61.speaker: Player
61.text: Death. We will butcher the ghaik, and free Orpheus from its grasp. Gith's Heir will rise once more!

47.speaker: Player
47.text: I have your back. We will slay Orpheus.

51.speaker: Player
51.text: So it must be. Vlaakith demands we sever the prince's blasphemous head.

81.speaker: Player
81.text: Without the Orphic Hammer, we may not be able to free the prince.

18.speaker: Player
18.text: I will not let the prince suffer another moment in this infernal prison!

71.speaker: Player
71.text: Gith's Heir will rise once more!

57.speaker: Player
57.text: Without the Orphic Hammer, we may not be able to reach the prince, let alone kill him.

79.speaker: Player
79.text: Hammer or not, Vlaakith will not be denied!

62.speaker: Player
62.text: How would we free Orpheus? His cage is unbreakable.

59.speaker: Player
59.text: I will find a way. The prince mustn't suffer another moment in this infernal prison!

127.speaker: Player
127.text: We have no means of breaking Orpheus out. How will we kill him?

50.speaker: Player
50.text: I will find a way. Vlaakith will not be denied!

112.speaker: Player
112.text: Killing Orpheus could have disastrous consequences.

32.speaker: Player
32.text: I made my promise. I will not fail my queen on the basis of groundless fears or fickle whims.

98.speaker: Player
98.text: Do you expect the Emperor will just let Orpheus walk free?

20.speaker: Player
20.text: I expect not. Which is why we will split the ghaik open and let his silver blood spill.

130.speaker: Player
130.text: I made my promise. I will not fail Gith's son on the basis of groundless fears or fickle whims.

96.speaker: Player
96.text: I guarantee that Vlaakith's kith'raki will fly to our aid. The lich queen will not abandon me in my moment of need.

2.speaker: Player
2.text: The traitor prince is close. We must split him open; we must fulfil Vlaakith's command!

107.speaker: Player
107.text: |But we're nut dead, so that means the show isn't over.|

95.speaker: Player
95.text: The Emperor's plan failed - we need to come up with our own plan.

75.speaker: Player
75.text: Let's hope the Emperor has a better plan.

84.speaker: Player
84.text: |Hope wasn't very effective, given we're now here.|

65.speaker: Player
65.text: |So we're going to need to place our pieces on the board, so to speak.|

15.speaker: Player
15.text: We can make up our minds after we hear what the Emperor has to say.

49.speaker: Player
49.text: |At least he seems to enjoy chatting more than brain eating.|

116.speaker: Player
116.text: The Emperor has been manipulating us this whole time - it's proven it can't be trusted.

119.speaker: Player
119.text: Whatever helps us defeat the Netherbrain, I'm open to it.

4.speaker: Player
4.text: I'm not eager to unleash the orb - but if no other option presents itself...

99.speaker: Player
99.text: We have another option - the orb. I could still put a stop to this... though at great cost.

19.speaker: Player
19.text: You would bring us down with you? This is a coward's choice. Everything bleeds, the brain included, we just need to find where to strike it.

122.speaker: Player
122.text: Now we free Orpheus. Perhaps he can help us succeed where the Emperor failed.

28.speaker: Player
28.text: |I don't know about you, but I wouldn't be so pleased being woken up after an eternity of prison time.|
